extended_description: Temperature of the air 2m above Earth's surface. This is the measure of air temperature used for most modeling applications.
Total precipitation. Computed by summing total gridscale precipitation and total cumulus precipitation.
The percentage of water vapor (i.e. moisture) relative to the amount of water vapor needed to saturate the air at the current air temperature and pressure.
Wind speed at 10 meters above the Earth's surface. Computed by taking the vector magnitude of the west-east (u) component of wind and the north-south (v) component of wind.
The temperature the air needs to be cooled to, at constant pressure, in order to achieve a relative humidity of 100%.
Wind coming from the west, measured at 10m above Earth's surface. By convention, wind coming from the east is negative.
Wind coming from the north, measured at 10m above Earth's surface. By convention, wind coming from the south is negative.
Air pressure at Earth's surface.
The ratio of the mass of water vapor over the mass of dry air, measured 2m above Earth's surface.
Temperature of the Earth's surface (i.e., ground surface).  Typically not used in most applications.

long_name: instantaneous downwelling longwave flux at bottom
display_name: Instantaneous downwelling longwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Longwave radiation emitted by Earth's surface that is reflected back downwards by gasses and clouds.

long_name: instantaneous downwelling clear sky longwave flux at bottom
display_name: Instantaneous downwelling clear sky longwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Longwave radiation emitted by Earth's surface that is reflected back downwards by the atmosphere, excluding the effect of clouds.

long_name: instantaneous upwelling longwave flux at bottom
display_name: Instantaneous upwelling longwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Total amount of longwave radiation emitted by Earth's surface.

long_name: instantaneous upwelling clear sky longwave flux at bottom
display_name: Instantaneous upwelling clear sky longwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Total amount of longwave radiation emitted by Earth's surface excluding impacts of clouds.
The portion of the total incoming solar radiation that has been scattered (by the atmosphere, clouds, etc.) before reaching the Earth's surface.

long_name: instantaneous downwelling shortwave flux at bottom
display_name: Instantaneous downwelling shortwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Shortwave radiation from the sun that reaches Earth's surface, minus radiation reflected back to space by clouds or absorbed by the atmosphere.

long_name: instantaneous downwelling clear sky shortwave flux at bottom
display_name: Instantaneous downwelling clear sky shortwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Shortwave radiation from the sun that reaches Earth's surface, excluding impacts of clouds.

long_name: instantaneous upwelling shortwave flux at bottom
display_name: Instantaneous upwelling shortwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Shortwave radiation from the sun that is reflected by Earth's surface, some of which may be reflected or absorbed by clouds (i.e. not emitted to space).

long_name: instantaneous upwelling clear sky shortwave flux at bottom
display_name: Instantaneous upwelling clear sky shortwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Shortwave radiation from the sun that is reflected by Earth's surface back to space.

long_name: accumulated total grid scale snow and ice
extended_description: Portion of the total frozen precipitation, which consists of frozen rain, snow, sleet, graupel and ice pellets
Any form of precipitation (rain, snow, etc.) that is produced specifically by cumulus/cumulonimbus clouds. These are generally small clouds that bring heavy precipitation.
Any form of precipitation (rain, snow, etc.) captured by the model resolution (i.e. 45km). Small clouds (including cumulus clouds) typically are excluded from this.
The rate at which  water that has infiltrated the ground surface travels underground until it reaches a body of water (stream, river, etc.)
The rate at which water travels over the ground surface until it reaches a body of water (stream, river, etc.)
The amount of water on surface that would be present if all snow melted.
Temperature of the air 2m above Earth's surface. This is the measure of air temperature used for most modeling applications.
Total precipitation. Computed by summing total gridscale precipitation and total cumulus precipitation.
The percentage of water vapor (i.e. moisture) relative to the amount of water vapor needed to saturate the air at the current air temperature and pressure.
The temperature the air needs to be cooled to, at constant pressure, in order to achieve a relative humidity of 100%.
The average wind speed (magnitude) at 10m above the Earth's surface.
The maximum wind speed at 10m above the Earth's surface.
Air pressure at Earth's surface.
The ratio of the mass of water vapor over the mass of total (moist) air, measured 2m above Earth's surface.
Temperature of the Earth's surface (ground surface).
The minimum daily air temperature at 2m above the Earth's surface.
The maximum daily air temperature at 2m above the Earth's surface.

display_name: Instantaneous downwelling longwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Longwave radiation emitted by Earth's surface that is reflected back downwards by clouds.

display_name: Instantaneous downwelling shortwave flux at bottom
extended_description: Shortwave radiation from the sun that reaches Earth's surface, minus radiation reflected back to space by clouds or absorbed by the atmosphere.
Shortwave radiation from the sun that reaches Earth's surface.
Longwave radiation emitted by Earth's surface.

long_name: sensible heat flux at the surface
display_name: Sensible heat flux at the surface
extended_description: The movement of energy generated by a difference in temperatures between the surface and the atmosphere. By convention, positive sensible heat flux is directed from the surface up into the atmosphere.

long_name: latent heat flux at the surface
display_name: Latent heat flux at the surface
extended_description: The movement of energy generated by evaporation or condensation between the surface and the atmosphere. By convention, positive latent heat flux is directed  from the surface up into the atmosphere.
The energy gained or loss by the Earth's surface. By convention, positive ground heat flux is directed into the ground.
Portion of the total precipitation in the form of snow.
The total amount of liquid water present from ground to top of atmosphere, and is critical for assessing the influence of clouds on radiation.

The physical process by which liquid water in ground/surface enters the atmosphere, including evaporation and plant transpiration. By convention, negative evapotranspiration is condensation, in which a liquid forms.
The physical process by which a liquid is transformed to a gas. By convention, negative evaporation is condensation, in which a liquid forms.
Any form of precipitation (rain, snow, etc.) that is produced specifically by convective clouds. These are generally small clouds that bring heavy, or severe, precipitation.
The integral of ice water content through an ice cloud layer. IWP is critical for assessing optical properties of clouds and their influence on radiation.
The rate at which water travels over the ground surface until it reaches a body of water (stream, river, etc.)
The rate at which  water that has infiltrated the ground surface travels underground until it reaches a body of water (stream, river, etc.)
The maximum precipitation rate in a single hour.
The amount of water that would be present if all snow melted.
The percentage of water vapor (i.e. moisture) relative to the amount of water vapor needed to saturate the air at the current air temperature and pressure.
Total precipitation. Computed by summing total gridscale precipitation and total cumulus precipitation.
The minimum daily air temperature at 2m above the Earth's surface.
The maximum daily air temperature at 2m above the Earth's surface.
